This was achieved by instilling the value of hard labor in their hearts and minds.

Shram Sanskar Chhavani is a week-long annual boot camp where young boys and girls from all over the country congregate, make friends, get sensitized and work in harmony with nature, building check dams, cultivating barren land, cleaning forests and digging lakes through Shramadan (hard labor). Working together, regardless of caste, creed and religion, helps them to develop empathy, secular values, national integration and sensitization towards the marginalized section of society and environment.

Participants learn about current and potential challenges confronting the society and are encouraged to ideate and develop sustainable solution through interaction with their peers and subject matter experts on topics ranging from education, health care, livelihoods, agriculture, rural development and environmental conservation.

The camp started in 1967 and till date has more than 40,000 youths all over India and the world. It has pioneered various youth empowerment programs in India. It is believed that 4 out of 10 social workers, activists and entrepreneurs in Maharashtra have attended the camp at some point of time in their youth. Additionally, thousands of past campers have imbibed the learnings from the camp to excel in their respective professions like medicine, engineering, governance and research.

Other information:

 Date: 15th-23rd May (15-19th- Somnath ; 20-23rd- Anandwan) 
 Contact: +919689888501 
 Email: somnathcamp@anandwan.in 
 Last date for registration: 15th April, 2018. 
 Registration fee: Rs. 2,000 
 (Includes food, accommodation and travel expenses between Somnath and Anandwan) 
 Provide us your email id and we will certainly connect you to the Cor-ordinators of the Camp.

Maharogi Sewa Samiti, Warora (Leprosy Service Society) was established with the intention of treating leprosy patients and for society afflicted by mental leprosy. Baba chose to call this paradise Anandwan, meaning Forest of Bliss. Baba Amte knew that simply curing the disease wasnt enough.

It was important to create a self-sufficient, productive society made of these social outcasts. Starting with agriculture and expanding to various small and medium scale industries right from textiles to wood work, MSS, Warora has grown into the productive heaven of Babas dreams.

Established in 1949 with Rs.14, 6 leprosy patients and a lame cow, MSS, Warora has spread its work all over Maharashtra and many organizations have taken inspiration from Babas work and are working for the downtrodden across the country and even the entire world. The impact Baba Amte had across the world is immeasurable and a soul like his is a rare gem the world was lucky to have.

Nature has always integral part of Anandwan. The environment has always been linked with healing and Anandwan is a beautiful anandwan of human beings living with nature in harmony. It is an integral part giving back to nature.

Abhayaranya is spread over 60-65 acres of beautiful man-made but diverse landscape with a rich biodiversity. The land here was completely overrun by rock mines and was thus completely barren. Dr. Vikas Amte felt the need to completely rehabilitate this land and give it new life. However this land was forest land and belonged to the government when a request was made to acquire this land the government show the willingness to hand it over. Dr.Vikas Amte created a rough draft of his vision and began working towards building an entirely new ecosystem in place of the barren lands. The entire quarry was filled using soil which was put on a plastic base. Trees creepers flowering plants and vegetables were planted to build this ecosystem. Today this entire region which was once barren is now a beautiful dense forest with an enviable ecosystem.

Peacocks, wolves, jackals, wildcats, parrots, neelgais, wild boars, rabbits, ducks and a variety of snakes including pythons can be found here. When abhayaranya was established, and had deer, monkey, neelgai, crocodiles,etc. But later, these animals were handed over to the forest department. Currently, we have ducks, emus, chickens, pigeons, rabbits, guinea pigs and dogs here.

The nursery in this area has 100s of varieties of flowering plants, fruit plants and medicinal and other essential trees. This plants are used to plant trees all over Anandwan, Somnath, Mulgavhan and the rest are sold. There are 2 lakes in Abhayaranya to maintain groundwater levels and to ensure plentiful water in the area. The trees in abhayaranya is also responsible for providing usable wood (amounting to 100s of tonnes) from the time Anandwan was established till today. Baba Amte used to say Be friends with the trees, you cannot have a difference of opinion with them. Keeping this principle in mind and heart, abhyayaranya has, in the period of 30 years, slowly evolved into an enviable landscape, attracting a ton of visitors every year.

The entire world is focusing on sustainable development and MSS in not the exception. India being agricultural country, to achieve sustainable development in this field on a greater scale, Anand Agriculture Polytechnic College was started in Anandwan in 2010. A social organization, Syngenta Foundation for sustainable Agriculture, funded for this college. This college is associated with Dr. Panjabrao Deshmukh Agriculture University, Akola. Plant protection, dairy technology, soil and water analysis, bee breeding, organic fertilizers, floriculture are some of the important subjects taught in the polytechnic.

The collegehas capacity of 180 studentsand has 50 acres of land to perform various agricultural experiments. The polytechnic also conducts short-term courses for agriculture aid sellers, seminars for farmers by agro experts along with the technology trainings by state government and private institutions. To create awareness amongst farmers about latest, profitable and economical farming technologies and to educate them on the same is the foremost aim of this college.

Maharogi Seva Samiti conducts many social awareness and wellness projects under its banner. Strissue is one such project. The donations and help given to MSS by socially aware well-meaning citizens takes various forms. Of course money is donated but along with that, old and new clothes, utensils, furniture, shoes, books, electronics, toys, satranji carpets etc. are donated to the organisation. The first stage involves, the classification of all the material and everything useful is given to the people of Anandwan, as well as the poor Adivasis who live in Hemalkasa, Mulgavan, Nagepalli, etc. Jeans, Purses made of zari, small bags, satranjis, doormats, etc. are made and sold here which also helps support the organisation financially.

The second stage involves focusing on various womens issues. Spreading awareness amongst the women of Anandwan and its neighbouring villages about menstruation and the various misinformation and superstitions surrounding it. Along with this, awareness is spread about hygiene maintenance and the importance of a balanced and nutritious diet. One of the most important things done here is educating women about the use of sanitary napkins and making use of cotton as material for producing them at home. Training is provided to these women to help them to make sanitary napkins as well as use them. Along with Anandwan, the neighbouring villages of Kheregav, Parsoda, Majra 1,Majra 2, Borda have been surveyed and work has been done there. This department is headed by Pallavi Amte. Sarika Sausagade and 18 others assist her in this noble venture.

Swaranandwan is platform for leprosy-stricken, specially albled people where they forget their disability, develop confidence to face the society and thereby change societys perspective. Swaranandwan makes people bubble with untiring enthusiasm and happiness. Socially marginalized people like blind, deaf and mute, handicapped, cured leprosy patients are otherwise just like normal people having like-dislikes, wishes, ambitions, hobbies, and special capabilities. But still they may not get the right opportunity due to the situations around. Though cured of diesease and trained to work independently, the chances of their acceptance back in the family and society are meagre. Some of these are physically challenged people have melodious voice; some are good dancers while some have ability as a mimic. Realizing theselatent talents, Dr. Vikas Amte initiated a musical ensemble, Swaranandwan.

Initially, Swaranadwan was financially supported by organizations like and #39; Share and care #39; USA and UNICEF through the Government of Maharashtra, Nouvelle Planete, Switzerland to name a few.The orchestra first debuted on July 14,2002. A renowned poet Kusumagraj term this performance as Anandwan tumchya dwari whereas Ashok Hande named it as Swaranandwan. Starting with simple performances of Babas poems, Bharat Jodo movement songs, Hindi songs, today this a super large orchestra, one of kind, incorporating nearly 100 artists challenged with leprosy and different disabilities. It also runs a music academy for studies upto Visharad level. Swaranandwan has toured throughout the country and has hundreads of performances to its record. Swaranandwan manifests great works with tunes, words, rhythms, acts and thunderous applause from audience is just unstoppable. For Dr. Vikas Amte , it is a dream in reality with widening horizons. The team not only is not self-reliant but also contributes to the social cause. As rightly conceptualized by Dr. Vikas Amte , it is a therapeutic theatre rejuvnating the creative talents of socially marginalized people and rehabilitating them in true sense. Dr. Vikas Amte has planned to establish a special village called Himmatgram for these artists. Sadashiv Tajne who himself is physically challenged, handles the entire responsibility of Swaranandwan very efficiently.

A unique blend of artand skill, our wood art department is both awe inspiring as well as thought provoking. Disabled artists breathe life into each of the beautiful art pieces made by them and surprise and inspire all those whocome here. Mr. Chandramani Maharana is responsible for nurturing this department. A former Nexalite he lost his arm in a struggle against the police when he was hit by a bullet. He came to Anandwan after contracting leprosy and never looked back. He even made himself a wooden artificial limb to aid him in his work! Baba gave him the responsibility for this department knowing that Chandramanis family had been involved in woodworking for generations. Today, the wood art department has been handed over to Mr.Chandramani Maharanas apprentice Mr. Govinda Khopde who handles this department with flair, skill and passion. Mr. Govinda Khopde joined this department with his wife Mrs.Sunita Khopde after they left Somnath. Mr. Govinda Khopdes is his bottle art in which creates beautiful art pieces painstakingly joined one by one inside a glass bottle. He creates all the materials himself as well. His other USP is the intricate carvings he makes out of a single piece of wood. The intricate designs, carvings found in this department and the infinite variety of items found here are a source of wonder to all those who come here. However, the items found here are not for sold. Baba believed that the art found here is priceless, because at the end of the day, money cannot measure the talentand effort of the artist. Inspite of being over 50, this couple has not slowed down. In fact, they keep creating new art in their studio. They have amassed a huge collection of art throughout the years and it will impossible to put a number on the pieces they have created. But some of the things they have made include a Ganpati made of coconut shells, bamboo stands,table lamps,unique balancing toys, wooden animals, etc. Our wood art department is unique in the sense that no trees are cut in the name of art. The Khopdes satisfaction reflects clearly on their faces and their happiness shines through their art. Anandwan truly has the capacity to incorporate every talent in its fold and we are proud to have a variety of talents in our little family.

The number of rehabilitated lepers and patients increased day by day, however the number of people going back home decreased. Maharogi Sewa Samiti took all these people in. slowly these people became older and it became necessary to take special care of them. With the help of Help Age India Snehasavali was established and became a home for the old. Snehasavali is a success for humanity.

Other than just old people, this old age home also takes responsibility for the bedridden and all their needs including and limited to medicine, residence, food etc. Snehasavali includes 4 buildings that follow simple and pleasing patterns of comfortable individual rooms (some for men and some for women) and a garden in the middle of the building for the residents to enjoy. Baba Amte fondly referred to these patients as cold war horses and said : They may have lost the battle but have won the war against the disease (leprosy). The rise of rehabilitated lepers is filled with problems and issues we cannot fathom. Some are blind, some are handicapped and some are bedridden. Baba Amte believed that these people should die with dignity.

More than 400 people are fed, clothed and taken care of happily by the people of Anandwan. Even those old people without any support or family who arent patients of leprosy are welcome here. Baba Amte and Sadhana Tai went to Snehasavali everyday to meet and talk to residents there. To this day, Dr. Vikas Amte and his family, 3 generations after Baba meet the patients regularly. After death, the residents last rites are conducted the way they would be by family. The dignity and pride allowed to the residents is really reflected by the way they live and their happiness and satisfaction can be seen on their faces.

Baba wanted to save the wood and pollution that occurs in a funeral pyre. Instead a pyre, his hope was to be buried and a tree planted on his memorial. He wanted to be buried with his companions. Today, Baba has created an ideal for the world to follow and even today, one can see his thoughts and teachings in action everywhere.

Babas , tais memorial, Anama Vrukshanchi Smaranshila, Anama Muka Kalyanchi Smaranshila has a become a place of awe where people get inspired from their teachings and change their lifestyles to become better people and work for others with selflessness. Shraddhavan has become a place of inspiration beyond just the beautiful landscape. The area connected to Abhyaranya is called Shraddhavan. This is the final resting place of Baba Amte and Sadhana Tai. It is a place of faith, love contemplation, inspiration and awe.

Not just Baba and Tai, Count Arthur Tarnowski who worked tirelessly to give dignity and job prospects to the disabled, Babas good friend from Pune Dr. Dhairyashil Shirole, and many of Baba Amtes friends and helpers mostly rehabilitated lepers themselves have been led to rest here. Shraddhavan has a large amount of metaphorical importance, because in the same way people here gave their lives up to help others, even in death they gave the trees growing there a new life. There is a plant grown in every memorial. In memory of these great people and the wonderful work they did, 1000s of trees were planted here. The place brings great hope and happiness inspite of being the final resting place of many great souls. In font of Babas memorial lays the final resting place of the countless unnamed victims of female foeticide called Anama Muka Kalyanchi Smaranshila this memorial serves to remind society of gender inequality and its horrific results. It urges you to remember these girls and forget this inequality. Another memorial lies in front of Babas memorial, Anama Vrukshanchi Smaranshila which serves as a constant reminder of the countless trees that were cut during the establishment of Anandwan.

Shirdi Saibaba Hospital provides free medical services to leprosy patients, physically handicapped, deaf, mute and blind people, students of schools and colleges and the needy people from surrounding villages. Dr. Bharati Amte (MBBS and D.C.H) takes care of this hospital as a medical officer. Her daughter Dr. Sheetal Amte-Karajgi assists her in this work. Established in 1978, this is a non-governmental hospital run by MSS and offers medical services to people right from its inception.

After 1990, new hospital building was constructed with the funding received from Shamdasani Foundation and was named as Shirdi Saibaba Hospital. It has a capacity of 6 beds with facilities of OPD, laboratory and 3 well-equipped operation theatres. If the patients need urgent expert help, Doctors from Chandrapur are consulted for treatments. The local cases requiring urgent surgical treatments and advanced medical investigations are referred to Kasturba Hospital, Sevagram, Wardha.

A dedicated ambulance is available for this service. Hospital premises has reputed Naturopathy, Allopathy and Yoga training center that compliments the health recovery of patients. Cured and rehabilitated patients work here as a support and nursing staff. Every year, MSS organizes free diagnostic and surgical camps for cataract and reconstructive surgery along with the dental check-up and family planning camps. Thousands of peoples from the neighboring districts and states are immensely benefitted from these camps. The hospital started units for making special artificial limbs in 2007for patients needing prosthetic care. Here artificial limbs are provided to leprosy-affected patients, needy people of Sandhiniketan and outside community. Doctors from Nagpur help in this work to a great extent. The expenses for artificial limbs are borne by MSS and the hospital serves patients for 24 hours.

Anandwan was expanding day by day and thus, it became parallely important to expand the various activities in the industrial area. Dr. Vikas Amte began thinking about activities rehabilitated lepers could be engaged in.mr. Sudhakar Kadu suggested starting a Satranji (mat) department to Baba Amte and Dr. Vikas Amte. This idea was enthusiastically nwelcomed by Dr. Vikas Amte and he gave the responsibility of the department in Mr. Kadus able hands. Material was immediately ordered from Nagpur, however, some material couldnt be found. Dr. Vikas Amte himself made the materials that werent found. In this manner, the Satranji department was established in 1975.

This department is still thriving. Rehabilitated lepers, the disabled and handicapped are running this department in a capable manner and have a made this department a success. 68 threads are crisscrossed in a 1 foot width on a 54 vertical tana threads and horizontal bana threads. Number 6 (thickness) thread is used to manufacture the Satranjis. The wooden instruments required for manufacture are also made here. On an average, one worker manages o make 3 square feet of Satranji in a day. Currently there are about 25 workers in this department. Mr. Fago Ganvir has been head of this department for the last 40 years. Along with the large Satranjis, small personal mats are also made here. According to the demand, colors and design are customized which makes them very popular in the market.

Leprosy is not a repercussion of sins committed in previous lives. Neither is it a curse. It is caused by a bacterium called MycoBacterium Leprae and is an illness just like any other. It is not contagious and does not target any particular task, community or gender but affects people with very low immunity or resistance power. This bacterium was discovered by Dr. Hensen on 28th’ February, 1873. It commonly manifests itself through development of tumors, red patches on skin, fever, body ache, muscular weakness and infection among others.

Once infected nerves become thicker with the skin losing sensation eventually. Our organization primarily works towards the treatment and rehabilitation of leprosy patients. This work was started Baba Amte himself in 1949 when he came here with just 1 lame cow and 6 leprosy patients with him. SEETA RATAN HOSPTAL has constantly been working towards treating leprosy afflicted people medically as well as psychologically by working on developing their confidence. Dr. Vikas Amte accepted the responsibility of the hospital after attaining his medical degree. Since 1982, Dr. Vijay Paul has been working as a special medical officer (SMO) here after undergoing a special training in leprosy treatment at Wardha.

The hospital has an OPD, dressing stations, a ward with a 75 bed capacity, a well-equipped operation theatre, pathology lab, digital X-ray unit, physiotherapy unit, dining hall and office since 2002. All the patients here are looked after by nurses and assistants staff, who are themselves cured leprosy patients. The hospital also follows the unique practice of allocating every patient his own identity number .

As MSS started to grow, so did its workload. As a result, Baba decided to invest a grand sum of Rupees 50,000 in1963 for setting up a printing press keeping in mind its usefulness in expanding the industrial setup by and by. At that time, the unit was managed by Diwarkar Mohani who trained 22 leprosy patients with the know-how of the trade. As time passed, the unit started to receive work orders from nearby villages. Later, Gangareddy Totawar encouraged and guided the cured leprosy patients to take full responsibility of the unit.

He was succeeded by Ramdas Kandarkar in 2008. From the days of using nail work technology to using Type Setting technology today, the unit has exhibited an exponential growth. The high quality of the products manufactured here has also attracted work orders for magazines that are inspired by Sane Gurujis thoughts such as AANTAR BHARATI. MSSs publications, stationery for in-house use, office stationery, files and envelopes, journals, for our schools and colleges, notebooks and other printing and binding related work is undertaken here besides taking orders from outside. We have also undertaken work orders from sectors like the Forests and Mineral department. Today, the press is run by 18 visually challenged, hearing impaired and cured leprosy patients and generates an annual income of 12-15 lakhs making it a very essential department of MSS.

To improve scope of the cottage industries at Anandwan, it was imperative to increase productivity of the existing units. With this thought in mind, Baba decided to upgrade the handloom department to increase cloth production. MSS acquired a government license for setting up a power loom unit with Mumbais textile genius Dilip Herlekar taking responsibility for installing the department at Anandwan at a friends gathering in 1983. In the same year, 4 good quality secondhand power looms were purchased and installed here. Mr. Herlekar was also instrumental in training the leprosy patients in operating and maintaining those machines.

The improved cloth production helped in meeting the need of the organization besides facilitating generation of revenue by sale of the surplus produce. Later, Sable-Waghire and Company gifted 4 new power looms with the total number being 22 today. The excellent quality of the products has also attracted MNC’s like L and T to place orders with us. What is extraordinary is the fact that this success has helped in reducing the stigma associated with leprosy by bridging the gap between the two sides significantly. The 30 workers in this department help in generating lakhs of rupees as revenue each year with their unmatched hard work and dedication.

Anandwan has always been about inclusiveness and giving dignity to everyone in society. Unity, nationalism and conservation of our environment have always been a priority here. However, the ever growing population and the resulting pollution has been a big concern everywhere in the world and we felt the need to be proactive and increase our afforestation efforts. In this vein, Dr. Akira Miyawakis afforestation method of growing a forest 10 times faster with 100% survival became our weapon of choice to battle global warming and rapidly decreasing forest cover of the world.

Miyawaki method involves using various local plants and trees and planting them in a 100 x 20 square feet plot. The soil is dug up to 3 feet and is filled with wheat or rice husks, cow dung and jeevamrut to form a soil bed. This method is assured to create a forest without sacrificing local biodiversity; in fact it embraces local biodiversity and attempts to create a natural forest. When this experiment became successful, Miyawaki forests were cultivated on a large scale throughout Anandwan and Somnath. The style in which the forest is built involves planting various types of trees which can be broadly classified into 4 types.

To create a dense forest cover, canopy trees which will eventually grow 50 meters or taller are planted, followed by trees which grow from anywhere between 15 to 50 meters, sub trees which grow from 6 to 15 meters and shrubs which grow from 2 to 6 meters. About 3.5 plans fit in a single square meter. They are planted in a zigzag formation to replicate nature. The mulching of the husks reduces water requirement significantly and also dissipates heat. An efficient use of all the resources including sunlight and the way the forest is planted helps increase the pace of growth multi-fold compared to a natural forest. This project will help revive the dying biodiversity and will help the animal and forest conservation efforts. This method is 100% organic and is promised to be 30 times denser and 10 times faster than natural forest growth. Anandwan has always been the caretaker of the future. We wish to create a world which is a pleasure to live in. Through projects like these, we give life to our vision of a better, greener future.

Raising children is not easy task. For many of Anandwans physically challenged residents, there are added concerns and challenges. Recognizing the difficulties faced by these parents, Maharogi Seva Samiti : Muktangan Anganwadi was introduced in 2010. The intention behind Muktangan Anganwadi is to help overall physical and mental well-being and advancement of the kids who come there. A lot of the couples who have been rehabilitated here are engaged in some or the other work.

Muktangan Anganwadi is where such working parents send their children. This is a unique venture because it isnt just a daycare for the children but a wellness centre especially for the children of the disabled. Muktangan Anganwadi compensates wherever the parents of these children are unable tom do so. Special attention is given to the health and overall well-being of children from ages 1-3. To attend to the training required for child development, 3 experts from the institution : Umeed (Hope) have been engaged here. Special attention is paid to the children of the deaf and dumb so they may feel heard

. Through continuous assessment and constant attention both special talents and faults are recognized and efforts are made to either encourage or develop the same and lead the children to a successful life. Diet is also a primary focus here. Children are fed various different and nutritious foods and the cook makes as any as a 100 different varieties of items. Efforts are made to include a diet including milk, fruits etc containing various vitamins and essential nutrients. Parents are educated about raising the children and ensuring their well-being. Along with a healthy diet, children are given education and special effort is made to inculcate and nurture arts and sports activities.

The successful establishment of the greeting cards department was the motivation behind setting up of an independent poster department. The department is headed by Sheikh Gani Khan, earlier an artist in the greeting cards section. Recycled plastic and agriculture waste is used for making posters. Other non-biodegradable objects like used saline-bottles, cold drink bottle caps, guthka wrappers, cigarette packets are used to make chandeliers, different craftworks, etc. all these ingenious ideas gave a huge impetus to the work here and helped them gain massive popularity in a short span of time.

Today, more than 30 designs are visible in a poster section and many of these are available for sale as well. All the 10 artists working here are differently able or cured leprosy patients and create more than a 100 beautiful posters every month. Dr Vikas Amte is still actively involved in the creation of few new designs every year. We have also successfully experimented with using bio-medical waste in the form of screen printing on X-ray films for making calendars. One of Sheikh Gani Khans masterpieces includes creation of portraits without any use of color. Instead, he uses dried banana leaves, rice husks and com coverings to enhance minute facial details of many famous personalities. It takes Gani 10 straight days of hard labor to create a masterpiece usually. This department is commonly called a place for makeovers of waste products into beautiful masterpieces.

Greeting cards have always been considered a more personalized and affectionate medium of expression of emotions. It is this very thought that motivated Dr. Vikas Amte to use his mode for Anandwan to communicate both internally as well as with the outside world. This would not only facilitate building deeper relations with Anandwans fraternity, donors and friends but also give an impetus to increase productivity sale. Ideas for different designs were initially adopted from greetings that were sent to MSS were reproduced onto smaller sizes with the use of waste products as raw materials.

For 42 years, Ramesh Amru with Dr. Vikas Amte has spearheaded the growth of this department by conquering the impediments posed by manifestation of leprosy onto his body. On Dr. Vikas Amte’s insistence, waste produced from other departments was also used to create exquisite pieces of art. Organic substances like banana, leaves, ripped clothes, dried barks, colored paper, etc are the main raw materials that are being used here. The department specializes in creating cards out of sewing threads onto paper and every year. Ramesh Amru and his team strive to create 5-6 new designs having created more than a 100 designs so far. Big festivals like Diwali and New Year understandably render a huge market for these products. Besides, these cards are in high demand at Mumbais Grahak Peths, an yearly exhibition, where we are able to see more than 60,000 cards each year in the price range between 20-41. Handcrafted paper made notepads, letter pads, paper diaries, are some of the other objects produced by the 30 artists working here. These cards have actually helped Anandwan in bridging the gap between its reality and perception by the world outside. Ramesh Amru considers Dr. Vikas Amte as his inspiration and does not shy away from admitting this ever.

The skillful work by the rehabilitated lepers of Anandwan impressed the country as well as the entire world. The inspiring stories of Anandwan spread, and the number of patients began to rapidly increase. This led to a direct increase in Maharogi Seva Samiti’s economic burden. Compensate for the increasing need for jobs as well as to reduce the economic burden on the organization, Baba Amte decided to introduce spinning (turning cotton to thread) and handlooms to Anandwan besides agriculture, which was already thriving.

Some residents from the weaving community decided to take responsibility and run the handlooms. An additional advantage was the self-sufficiency that came to Anandwan with the need for clothes for the residents, producing gauze and bandages in Hemalkasa, Somnath and Ashokwan, relatively new ventures at the time. This work continues till date. Currently 26 disabled and rehabilitated lepers including 7 women are working on making Shabnam bags, personal mats, bedsheets, rugs (Galichas), blankets, towels, napkins, panchas , lungis , shirting etc. the raw material from Nagpur is turned into finished products here.

Previously, colored thread had to be ordered, however, now that processes take place here as well. There are 22 handlooms which include all a tall beam for threads, charkhas to make thread rolls. The cloth manufactured here are in immense demand. The workers work according to their comfort and capability and are paid accordingly, Mr. Nana Makte was in charge of the handlooms for a long period of time, and after him, his apprentices have taken responsibility of the handlooms. Various well wishers of Anandwan use these materials for special occasions and in their daily lives. Because of the first class quality, the skillful work and the goodwill for Anandwan, sales here are superb.

Anandwan subscribers to the saying : Those who dine together, stay together . Every single person who stays here is a part of the Anandwan family and is thus welcome to enjoy the community dining experience. As the Anandwan family began to grow and expand with time, Baba built the rehabilitated leprosy afflicted, disabled citizens homes and communities as they started settling down, getting married and having children.

The different communes like Sukhsadan, Muktisadan, Krushi Niketan, Mitrangan and the guest mess all came to have their own kitchens and canteens. This resulted in a difference in the food in different places. This continued for many years. However, everyone felt like the whole village should dine as one and this thought gave birth to the proposal for a Megakitchen . Nouvelle plan te, Switzerland and Fedvaco made this dream a reality and with their help, our Megakitchen was built in 2004. Typically, one can expect 3 square meals a day here, Everything from breakfast, tea, roti , vegetables, dal, rice etc is served everyday.

More than 2000 people currently dine here. For those who find coming to the kitchen inconvenient, food is delivered to their area and for some others Tiffins are given. All rations required making the nutritious, tasty and balanced variety of food found here is bought from Nagpur and Warora. The Megakitchen makes use of advanced technology like roti makers, biogas and solar panels to cook food. These methods have reduced LPG use by around 75%. 2 cooks and more than a 100 helpers and cleaners work here. The Megakitchen has a big dining hall, clean filtered drinking water, a large kitchen area and a godown. The Megakitchen encourages the feeling of unity and helps reduce manpower and wastage of food as well. The Megakitchen is one of the places that encapsulate what Anandwan is truly about. A feeling of community and family.

BABA Amte always worked towards making the lives of lepers independent and ensured that they would live in a dignified manner. Count Arthur Tarnowski a foreigner himself affected by polio and thus paralyzed from the waist down, was greatly inspired by Baba Amte and Anandwan. It filled his heart with joy to see lepers living their lives in a dignified and fulfilled manner, so much so that he knew that if there was anyone in the world who could build a sustainable institution for the disabled, to learn, grow and thrive, it was Baba Amte.

He requested Baba Amte to consider taking up the cause for the disabled as well. Baba Amte was of the opinion that though someone may be disabled, it doesnt necessarily mean, they cannot be self sufficient, in fact they are capable of leading life independently and finding the meaning of life. And so, it was decided that Anandwan would build its own institution for the disabled. In 1967, Count Arthur Tarnowskis book : The Unbeaten Track , was published and was successful.

A total sum of Rs. 15 lakhs collected by the Count as book royalty was then donated to MSS to begin work on the training center as well as residential quarters for the disabled, Baba Amte was of the opinion that be it lepers or the disabled, society must set aside its pre-conceived notions and give them a chance, not charity. Thus, the training center was named Sandhiniketan or the home for opportunity. Work on this project was completed in the year 1970. Free residence and jobs are given to the disabled. In this venture, Mr. Tarnowskis Take Heart foundation continues to back MSS. Courses like fashion designing, tailoring, wireman, wielding, weaving, printing press, leather works, housekeeping, medical assistant, caregiver, handicrafts are taught Mr. Sadashiv Tajane was the first student of the institution.

He later went on to become the principal of this institution in1995. Mr. Ravindra Nalgintavar is currently the principal of this fine institution. The institution which was independently run by the MSS later began to get funding and recognition from the government. The government provides funding for 85 trainees. However the training center has more than 100 students. In addition to this, psychological guidance is given to the trainees. The focus remains on making them as self- sufficient and economically independent as possible. Artificial limbs are provided to the trainees as required to make their lives simpler and make it easier for them to work. After the completion of the course, the institute attempts to place every student. Additionally, efforts are made to help with loan applications in case student wishes to start a business. Till date, hundreds of students have been placed in over 78 different business fields all over places like Nagpur and Pune. These placements have resulted in the disabled trainees getting dignified jobs and thus, living independent lives.

IN 1960 ALONG WITH Anandwans Tin Can Project , a project where cans to store goods were made out of tin, the metal fabrication department was established. In the beginning the metal fabrication department was capable only of satisfying the residents demand. Because wood was so unwieldy to work with, the demand for metal products increased rapidly. Mr. Giridhar Raut, a rehabilitated leper, took charge of the department. The department was established, but nobody had any training. In the beginning, drawings were made and followed through.

These experiments were surprisingly successful. The acquisition of a wielding machine sparked a lot of creativity and passion amongst the workers and they began to experiment extensively. A direct result of these experiments was the manufacture of everything from iron chairs to car repair. Air coolers, deep freezers, and even Air conditioners were made here. For a few years, Anandwan even assembled thermostats for Voltas for a few years. The infinite variety of items and innovations in this department are a testament to Dr. Vikas Amtes vision.

The biggest success of this department is perhaps the 3 wheeled cycles. The introduction of the 3 wheeled cycle to Anandwan brought a lot of happiness an brought a lot of positivity among the disabled, handicapped residents. The 3 wheeled cycle gave them the gift of independence and movement, something we take for granted. The production as impressive and satisfied not only the demand of the residents of Anandwan, but subsequently were put up for sale. This helped spread the positive impact of the 3 wheeled cycles everywhere, even outside Anandwan. Something special to be noted about this department is that cycle repair, removing punctures is done here free of charge and as quickly as possible. Anandwans metal fabrication department is one of the only factors in Maharashtra with a production capacity of more than a 1000, 3 wheeled cycles per year. The Social Welfare department of Maharashtra directly gives their orders to Anandwan, without any tender. Some of the work taking place in the metal fabrication department currently includes iron beds, around 100 cupboards, rums to store grains, items made of tin, making chairs as well as any weaving required to manufacture the chairs, wielding etc. Mr. Prashant Deshmukh heads this department and currently, around 35 workers are engage in manufacture here. Raw material is acquired here from Nagpur, and mostly, orders are placed here by the government. This department satisfies the demand not just in Anandwan, but manages to satisfy the demand in Hemalkasa, Somnath, Ashokwan, Nagepalli, and Mulgavhan.

Starting new ventures and replicating them if successful is Anandwans motto.The bag and cushion section is a golden anandwan of the same. Anandwan is responsible for the rehabilitation of many handicapped and disabled people. Mr.Maniram Lunje, a worker in the leather department is one of them. Baba Amte had once received a leather bag as a gift from the Birlas. When Baba showed Mr.Lunje the same, he replicated it exactly and brought it to Baba and proved that we could produce quality leather bags in Anandwan.In 1985, an independent Bag and cushion section was establised. Leather purses, bags,backpacks,office bags etc.Along with leather, the factory began producing Rexin.

Rexin is cheaper than leather and so the demand for rexin products began increasing rapidly. The cushions required by Anandwan too are manufactured here. 8 disabled workers are engaged in manufacture here and they work with the help of sewing machines. These workers have all been trained here itself. Mr.Maniram Lunje has a talent for sewing and design. He makes an effort to keep abreast with the latest designs in the market and reproduce them here. The variety fo goods produced is staggering and impressive. It is in high demand here at Anandwan among residents and guests alike.

Apart from leprosy-afflicted people,many other physically challenged and neglected categories of society need help and opportunity. Realising this need, Baba Amte started a blind school in 1966. It was the first blind school of the time in Central India. In 1970, as a result of relentless efforts of MSS, Samajkalyan Sanchanalay, Pune granted permission to this school. Baba initially appointed Mukund Vaishampayan as Head of the school. Later Sudhakar Kadu handled this responsibility. Children from surrounding districts like Chandrapur, Gadchiroli,Nagpur,Bhandara,Gondiya and Yavatmal come to this school. Their physical limitation is never a restraining factor.

These children treated just like other normal kids and made part of all the activities of Anandwan. Along with this, Anandwan takes care of their health as well. Since 2001-02, Social Welfare Department has granted funding for educational material,stay,food,health and educational excursions of 75 students and additional 25 students are allowed on non-grant basis. The expenses of these 25 students is taken care by MSS.

The stay in well-equipped hostel and the education eith the help of latest teaching aids, CDs,DVDs and brail script, is provided upto 10 th standard. The students are also trained in other activities like music, sports, dance etc. Presently Sevakram Bandgar shoulders the responsibility of the school. With a well-maintained library,expert teachers and special teachers appointed by organization, Anand Blind School is constantly helping hundreds of blind children to get good education and be self-reliant in their life.

Education is very important to establish yourself in the society. Nobody should be deprived of the education , was Babas opinion. After successful start of Anand Blind School, Baba decided to start a school for deaf and mute children. Organization called Netherland Committeefor Kinder Postal funded for school building and instruments required for deaf and mute children and the school was started on 1 st July 1983. In 1995, the permission was granted upto 5 th grade and in 2006, permission till 10 th grade was granted. Social Welfare Department funds 75 students for educational aids, stay, food, health etc.

Unfunded students are taken care by the organization. Presently more than 100 students are studying in this school. All the students acn avail of well-equipped hostel facility, nutritious food, clothes etc. School continuously upgrades itself understanding the newer teaching technologies and aids being developed for deaf and mute children. Apart from government teachers, organization also appoints teachers and sign language translator to train studnets in art, craft, sports, etc. The organization strives to rehabilitate needy people by making them self-reliant and raising their standard of living. The option of vocational training at Sandhiniketan is also made available to these students. Presently, a cured leprosy patient Sopan Hange heads the school.

The increasing population and resulting need for an increase in food production is a national problem. This issue was close to Babas heart and bothered him greatly. He realised that unless agriculture is modernised and improved these problems cannot be solved. At the time, colleges teaching agriculture sciences were very rare. On the village level, ensuring that farming tradition remained alive had become a difficult task. If the youth were educated, they often used education to get out of the agriculture business. Baba wished for the youth to not only be engaged in agriculture beacuase of lack of opportunities or education but to improve agriculture by gaining education and knowledge in the field. Providing top quality agricultural education was a way of ensuring that agricultural tradition remains not just alive, but thrives in India.

With this intention, Baba decided to start an agricultural department in Anandniketan college in 1965-66. The technology, the fields and all the other equipment necessary for training was provided in Anandwan itself. In 1969, Dr. Panjabrao Deshmukh Krushi Vidyapeeth, Akola was established and this department was connected to it. This department was then converted into Anandniketan Agricultural College, a college dedicated to the agricultural sciences. Through his amiable connections at Dr. Panjabrao Deshmukh Krushi Vidyapeeth, Baba managed to build a formidable teaching staffand gather people who were the best in there field to teach here. Babas vision for the college was that the youth who will graduate from here will go back to his village as an ambassador for modern agricultural methods and systems.

His hope was that these students will spread their knowledge and help the farmers in thier region, thus improving the lives of farmers all over India. The students from the very first batch of Anandnikeatan Agricultural College, gained the first and second rank among all the students in Dr. Panjabrao Deshmukh Krushi Vidyapeeth. This tradition of being rank holders is alive even today. Anandniketan Agricultural College follows the syllabus, rules and conditions layed down by Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), Maharashtra Council of Agricultural Education and Research, Pune and Dr. Panjabrao Deshmukh Krushi Vidyapeeth. A four year, 8 semester B.Sc Agriculture full-time degree course is offered here.

When Baba set up the MSS, neither did Warora nor any other nearby village offeredan opportunity to receive higher education. Those who were interested had no option but to go either Chandrapur or Nagpur to pursue higher education. In order to prevent the youth of Anandwan, nearby tribal areas and poor villages from losing out due to lack of options, Baba started this college in 1964. To accomplish Babas vision, MSS arranged for 2 lakh rupees through money saved by leprosy patients along with the Tin Can project benefits. 53 acres of land was purchased for the college project and the work was started towards its completion. The magnificent building we see today is the creation of our own leprosy patients for whom Baba said, This College is a gift from the leprosy patients to the society. Those who study here will witness the creativity and hard work of these leprosy patients and this will help in lessening the hatred in their hearts towards them.

Anand Niketan Science, Arts and Commerce College was granted recognition by the University Council of Rashtrasant Tukdoji Maharaj University, Nagpur immediately after it came into being and the batch started their curriculum in 1964-1965. Baba appointed the very best professors and lecturers as the college staff and Dr. Vikas and Dr. Prakash Amte happened to be the students of the first batch. Till today, many students have graduated from this college and many more seek admission every year. Besides imparting formal education, college also runs a Students Council, NSS, NCC, Science Forum, a Literature Society, Womens Studies, Population Studies and many other programs. Today, Anand Niketan College is continuously gaining acclaim and accreditations by successfully implementing new ideas and technologies. The main college body is governed by MSS. The college is now affiliated With Gondwana University of Gadchiroli district and is the most reputed college under its umbrella.

Many of the leprosy patients who come to Anandwan have wounds on their feet, hands and other body parts as a manifestation of contracting leprosy. As a result, appropriate footwear became a basic need for these patients, to care for those wounds. However, due to lack of adequate funds with the organization in the beginning, it was not possible to buy each and every patient a new pair of shoes. Soon, Baba came upwith an innovative idea to utilize waste tires for manifacturing footwear. Luckily, a few of the leprosy patients happened to be shoemakers by profession and as a result, this department came into existence and is one of the oldest departments in Anandwan. Unsurprisingly, Baba himself began to wear these very chappals until MCR i.e. microcellular rubber was used to refine the quality of the footwear manufactured here. Chappals made with MCR, are very soft and are created without the use of nails thus preventing exacerbation of wounds. MCR footwear is also advised for diabetic patients rendering a huge demand for this product.

Today, the rubber used to manufacture chappals is imported from the local market whereas earlier it had to be produred from Chennai and Kolkata. The challenge to continuously create new and attractive designs was eliminated gradually by observing and replicating the designs of the footwear worn by the visitors. Since then, our footwear has become more popular in the market. The school for vocational training - Sandhiniketan also imparts training to youth interested in learning this art. What can be termed as an extraordinary achievement is the fact that the people who are working in the footwear department today do not belong to any one caste such as Chambhars who were traditionally typecast as shoemakers since times immemorial: when ones caste dictated ones profession. Today, these artists are dexterous at making footwear even for differently abled people by taking their foot measurement. Many of the people in Anandwan also use footwear made by them.

Milk is a staple part of most Indians diets. However, getting milk was an uphill task as Anandwan was set up far from other human settlements. This difficulty was noticed by Vinoba Bhave and he then gave Baba the money to buy a cow. Baba Amte bought a lame cow with this money and thus, Anandwans dairy was established in 1951 and its activities were conducted alongside agriculture which was Anandwans main business at the time. The increase in cows and buffaloes and the sale of milk would have definitely helped with money, however Babas main intention behind starting the dairy was to bring Anandwan in contact with the outside world and mainstream society. People bought the top quality milk in the beginning, however once they found out this milk came from Anandwan they were very hesitant to buy it. They were afraid to drink the milk extracted by rehabilitated lepers and were especially hesitant about giving it to their children.

Purchase completely stopped because of this. This situation led to Sadhna tai herself milking the cows, buffaloes. People confirmed that this was the case before resuming purchase. With the expansion of Anandwan, sales reduced. Mr. Narayan Hakke took charge of the dairy during thid time.Post 2009, MSS decided to expand the dairy and to get more cows and buffaloes. Expansion of the dairy meant preparing high protein feed for the animals first. The dairy was built in a sustainable manner with fantastic ventilation and stable infrastucture. Primarily, the hygiene here is impeccable and dedicatedly maintained. Talented vets take care of the overall health of the animals. Every early morning and evening the animals are treated to soothing classical music. The dairy is run in a very modern manner. The cows and buffaloes are given token numbers and their produce is observed. These practices have resulted in an increasing of milk production. A lot of these animals have won many prizes in fairs and exhibitions. After Anandwans demand was satisfied, milk began to be sold outside.

The remainder was used to produce various milk products. However, once the demand for milk rose again, production of milk products was stopped. In 2009, the expanded and improved dairy made 32 lac rupees and in 2012-13, this number rose to more than 1 crore. Presently, milk is sold at rs 60 a litre. 800 litres milk is produced on a daily basis. Since 2014, regular milk testing for fat content, glucose, protein, water, minerals etc is conducted. The natural waste in this department is used to creat biogas. Chickens have also been kept in the dairy. They eat insects, ticks etc and help maintain the health of the animals. They also produce eggs. An ideal model for agriculture, dairy and poultry farming has been attempted here. The science of dairy farming is taught and training is given to encourage youth from village to take this up as a career.This also increases employment opportunities in the area. Mr. Gajanan Vasu is currently heading this department.

Anandwan is an institution which believes in being there for those who have no-one.Anandwan was establised by Baba Amte to be a firm support,a familly and a community for those who suffer from leprosy. with the same intention,Gokul was born.Tai and Baba Amte were well aware of the reality of life for orphans.They were worried about the future of such children and wished to give them a home to call their own,education and a chance of a better future.Sometimes,it became important to take care of the children of some lepers as the research for leprosy was not advanced enough and the cause for the same had not been found by science at the time.Once the research and experience showed that the children would not suffer like their parents,they were returned to their respective homes.In 1983, Some school children from Mumbai saved their pocket money to donate.

They gave the sum to the president of saneguruji Kathamala Mr.Prakash Mohadikar to give Baba Amte.This money was used to construct Gokuls building, All the children from Gokul are doing very well and currently 7 kids residing here are the children of lepers and 7 are orphans. Mr.Madhav Kavishwar and his wife Mrs. Neelatai Kavishwar have been taking care of the Gokul family for many years now.Along with their primary needs,the childrens educational needs are also fulfilled here. When the children grow up,MSS Also takes responsibility of rehabilitation these children intosociety. Gokul prides itself on being a home to the children who come here.

Anandvan function on two basic principles-local production of everything required for basic sustenance of life and utilization of all waste products to reduce waste to a bare minimum.with this thought in mind,the Biogas project was established in order to utilize kitchen waste and cow dung from dairy in 1978 under the guidance of Dr.Vikas Amte and Devendrabhai Gupta,an expert in biogas technology,the wholehearted dedication and hard work of te cured leprosy patient has brought this project into being.with the passage of time,regular changes werw incorporated at the plant.Today,the new technology used by us is created with the help of kirloskar integreated Technology limited.

Currently,we produce 150 Kgs i.e 400m 3 of biogas by treating 5 tons of cow dung, 3 tons of kitchen waste from local market and food waste from our commumes every day.Also 24 toilets are connected to this project.After the primary and secondary process is completed,the biogas is stored in a 150 kg capacity balloon.the byproduct-slurry is not discarded and rather used as organic manure for our agriculture thus,ensuring a healthy crop.Besides,regular use of biogas for making food at Mega kitchen has also helped in reduction of our consumption significantly.

Anandvan is village that was established on the function of hard and dignity. This was the place for rehabilitated lepers,the handicapped lepers, the handicapped or disabled tc find dignity in labour and life.Agriculture was the primary occupation at Anandwan and the need of wood for agricultural equipment,construction for new residences became the need of the hour.Baba Amte insisted that everything needed for MSS,should be made here at Anandawan,Some of the rehabillitated patients had some experience in carpentry,and so, the equipment and wood required for the new residences began to be made here.Some of the things made here.

Some include the framework for construction,doors,windows and before the metal fabrication department was established,even the beds,tables and cupboards were made here.Since the entire organisation,including the residences of the patients used wood for just about everything,the burden and worklosd of this department was intense, The materials need at Hemalkasa,Somnath,Ashokwan were also manufactured here.Mr,Namdevrao Tagad was the first te take charge of this department. Now, Mr Anandrao Chaudhary is currently in charge and 12 workers work here. This deprtment is still in high demand and is running smoothly due to various modernisations through time. The ban on cutting of forest wood, has forced the workers to stick to plywood. Along with the manufacture of doors, windows etc, a large amount of repair work also takes place here.

The school for the deaf and mute children saw the light of day in 1983. Art oriented education became the foundation of their curriculum, given the natural inclination exhibited by most of these children towards it. As a result, handicraft lessons were initiated to provide them a medium to exhibit their creativity. Motivated by Dr. Bharti Amte, Mangala Dumre, a teacher in the deaf and mute school began working here. Gradually, girls from the school who had been rehabilitated here and were adept at wool work joined the department.

department. The heavy winter of Anandwan made it imperative to produce woolens. Half and full sweaters, mufflers, caps, small frocks, jackets, baby sets for toddlers are some of the products created here in exquisite designs. Approximately, 50-60 woolen sets are created every month for sale. Today, four differently abled ladies work on 3 machines in this department. These donated machines have helped in increasing productivity by a huge margin. The raw material is procured from Nagpur while the new design samples experimented here are prepared at wardha.

Baba Amte as well his entire family has always been very passionate about education. It was very important to them to ensure that the children of those rehabilitated at Anandwan, the children from the Gokul orphanage as well the children from the neighbouring villages should be given first-class educational opportunities atleast but not limited to the primary level. The Zilla Parishad School was established as early as 1984 with this intention. From a humble beginning of of 25 students, now, more than 400 students are enrolled in the school. This school is popular not just amongst the residents of Anandwan, but with people from the neighbouring villages as well. The ZP school provides education from standards from 1 to 8 and is Semi-English medium to promote familiarity with both the mother tongue as well as the lingua franca of the World-English.

Along with a quality education, emphasis is given on a healthy school lunch, arts and sports among other extra curriculars. The students win many accolades and laurels for the school. The school is a well equipped building with a hand wash center, canteen, clean drinking water, hall, etc. It has been credited with the A Grade for its outstanding performance. Here, daily prayers takes place in Marathi and English alternatively. Under the able guidance of principal Geeta Pande and a team of teachers who care not just about providing quality education but holistic guidance and love to their students, Zilla Parishad school, Anandwan is growing from strength to strength everyday. The residents of Anandwan, too, encourage all new projects and activities undertaken by the school.
"The greatest joy comes in life when you invest in others "

1985 In recognition of Baba Amtes work to rehabilitate the leprosy afflicted and other differently abled outcasts. 2008 For Dr. Prakash and Dr. Mandakini Amtes contributions in improving the lives of tribals in a remote Maharashtrian village through medical care and education.

In recognition of Baba Amtes outstanding contribution to the rehabilitation of disabled leprosy patients which has resulted in restoring the will and capacity to live in dignity to tens of thousands of leprosy sufferers.
For Baba Amtes exceptional contribution to affirming lifes spiritual dimension through his work for the leprosy afflicted and other downtrodden parts of society.
Awarded to Baba Amte for being a living legend of our time and a shining anandwan of the Gandhian spirit and approach to current and compelling social problems of the country."
For outstanding achievements in the field of Human Rights.
Innovative Energy Project of the Year- Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy,The Association of Energy Engineers, USA
For Anandwans efficient energy use and innovative strides in solar energy.
To Baba Amte for outstanding contribution to humanism
Co- recipient Right Livelihood Award, Sweden 1992
Popularly called Alternate Noble Prize for Environment, The Right Livelihood Award was bestowed on Baba Amte for his exemplery work and participation in the Narmada Bachao Andolan.
Global 500- United Nations Environment Program Award 1991
For MSS, Waroras outstanding contribution towards the environment.
Dr. Ambedkar International Award for Social Change, 1999

In recognition of outstanding work done in pursuing the cause of the exploited and the underprivileged, reconciling differences among conflicting social groups and contributing significantly to social change
Baba Amte was conferred with an honorary D. Litt by Tata Institute of Social Sciences.
Mother Teresa Awards for Social Justice, 2014

Dr. Prakash Amte and his wife have toiled tirelessly under extreme hardship to help in the preservation of Indias tribals. His tribal welfare programmes have gained international recognition for their preservation of the culture of tribals of India.
For Dr. Vikas and Prakash Amtes outstanding contribution to society.
For Baba Amtes significant contributions in the field of social work and the welfare of people suffering from leprosy as well as the differently abled.
Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry Award (FICCI),1988
For outstanding achievements in training and placement of disabled persons.
For Dr. Vikas Amtes phenomenal environmental contributions and especially his work related to the creation of the biogas plant at Anandwan which has resulted in a 75% decrease in LPG use.
For Babas extraordinary work for the welfare of the leprosy afflicted.
For the organisations and Dr. Vikas Amtes extraordinary efforts to help farmers in the Vidharba region.
APANG MITRA Puraskar by the Helpers of the Handicaps, Kolhapur (1998)
For Dr. Vikas Amtes efforts to help the handicapped live productive, dignified lives.
KUSTHA MITRA PURSKAR by Vidarbha Maharogi Sewa Mandal, Tapovan, Amravati [1995]
For Dr. Vikas Amtes work for the upliftment and service of the leprosy afflicted. He has lived his entire life in their service and will continue to be a champion of the leprosy afflicted.
A commune specially built for women, to give them a comfortable home and privacy. Apulki was established after sneh-savali started getting overcrowded.
. It was built using the money raised by the ‘Swaranandwan’ orchestra. The residents here are provided with electricity, housing, food water etc.

This was the first commune established in Anandwan. The communes here were designed for the rehabilitated leprosy-afflicted and disabled people. Baba had arranged for two young couples and one older couple to stay in one home thus forming a traditional Indian joint-family."1

This way, family relations could be preserved and understood by those who were otherwise disowned by their blood relatives outside Anandwan. The joint-family structure ensures that the older couple can be taken care of by their “children”.
Water conservation is of utmost importance for the development of the region due to the scarcity of water.

The land on which Anandwan stands was originally barren, abandoned quarry with no surface water. Through the painstaking efforts by early rehabilitated residents, wells were dug to provide water for drinking, domestic and irrigation purposes. Considering the growing requirement of water, reservoirs were built which helped in recharging ground water of the region thus providing water security even during a drought year. More than 30 reservoirs have been built across various project locations of MSS. These reservoirs apart from supplying and recharging water also offer reprieve to the surrounding flora and fauna.

To enhance the catchment of reservoirs, small check dams were developed. These dams are low in cost and easy-to-build and are made using old tyres and plastic waste. With the help of these check dams’ water catchment of reservoirs has been enhanced manifold thus providing water security to the surrounding areas.

All the drains in Anandwan converge into two reservoirs, through a unique bio filtration system the water is treated and the fishes in the reservoir further cleanse the water thus allowing the water to be utilized for irrigation of farms. Also, sale of fishes creates livelihood opportunities.

The Vidarbha region in India is blessed with perfect geography for optimal utilization of solar energy. Various applications have been developed and deployed utilizing solar power for steam-based cooking, heating water and generating electricity to power utilities.

In the year 2016, Anandwan was awarded the Most Innovative Project of The Year by American Association of Energy Engineers for implementing integrated solar based project in Anandwan. The solar project has significantly helped in reducing energy costs and has created a benchmark for other villages to replicate.

Under the direction of the Anandwan Administrator, the Electric Department is responsible for maintaining, operating, and repairing a variety of mechanical equipment used in the electrical distribution system and street lighting system. In addition, and when directed by the Anandwan Administrator, the Electric Department shall perform tasks in other departmentsUnder the direction of the Anandwan Administrator, the Electric Department is responsible for maintaining, operating, and repairing a variety of mechanical equipment used in the electrical distribution system and street lighting system. In addition, and when directed by the Anandwan Administrator, the Electric Department shall perform tasks in other departments
Those who dine together, stay together.

Every single person who visits here is a part of Anandwan Guests family and is thus welcome to enjoy the community dining experience. All the guests who comes here can enjoy the delicious foods of Guest Canteen called "Atithi Bhojnalaya". one can have as many as food to eat , there is sufficient quantity of food every day, but there are fixed timings for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Yes there is also facility of breakfast in the morning .

Everything from breakfast , tea , vegetables, roti, dal, rice etc is served everyday. More than 100 people (guests) dine here everyday. All rations required here for making the delicious, nutritious, tasty and balanced variety of food is bought from Nagpur and Warora. The Bhojnalaya makes use of modern technology like roti makers, biogas and solar plant to cook food. The Atithi Bhojnalaya has a big dining hall, clean filtered drinking water, a large kitchen and a godown backside. The Bhojnalaya encourages the feeling of unity and reduces manpower and wastage of food as well.
Guests coming here have to take food by their own (Self-Service) and after having food they have to wash their utensils by their own; One can experinece the true Indian Culture here.

Anandwan is a place full of village culture, thus villages also includes different agricultural activities with cultivations of differnt plants and faunas. Conservation of Environment has always been a priority basis. Nursery actually is divided into two parts, the first one is called Ropwan and the second one is Muktangan Nursey.Ropwan is inside the Zoo premises.

In Ropwan variety of plants are planted and taken care of with some species of Cactus Flowers. And in Muktangan Nursery some plants of Ropwan are kept for selling, specially flower plants are sold here. Visitors as well as local peoples can buy this palnts from nursery . Alongwith these two the Miyawaki Forest is also there which is actually a experiment on cultivted plants. Here plants are grown 10 times faster than common plants growth.

Exhibition Centre is the place where the visitors can have a visit and can purchase products made by the peoples of Anandwan livivng there. All the products manufactured here with the help of handlooms, powerlooms and other handmade products are kept here for selling. Visitors purchase this products at a cheap cost but gives good quality of products. Products manufactured here are transported to Mummbai as well for Exhibitions and selling purposes.
Bags, Handbags, Purses and School Bags
Books of Sane Guruji and P.L. Deshpande piblications

string.name: info_2
string.p: Anandwan was established in 1949 by Baba Amte with a hope of giving marginalised people a dignified life through self-reliance and restoring a sense of belonging which they had lost due to the ill treatment at the hands of society.

resources.string: Anandwan is located in Chandrapur district of Maharashtra.

string.name: info_4
string.p: We believe that self-reliance and pride in one’s existence are very essential to lead a meaningful life. Baba Amte established Anandwan with a few leprosy patients and some savings.

string.name: info_5
string.p: Our mission is to bring back hope to those who have been shunned from society. Creating a sense of belonging through collective effort and providing people access to better healthcare facilities, quality education and an occupation of their choice, we give them the right and means to lead a successful life.

string.name: info_6
string.p: Initiatives in healthcare, education, agriculture and agro-industries, small and medium scale industrial units, renewable energy and conservation have been taken up by MSS. Anandwan can be termed as the Center for Rural Innovation and Incubation because a wide range of activities have been undertaken here over the years that have also been replicated in many villages across Maharashtra, such as construction of Nubian vault houses and man made lakes among many others.

string.name: info_7
string.p: Anandwan aspires to become a Smart village. The SMART (Sustainable, Measurable, Affordable, Replicable and Technologically advanced) village model is a holistic approach towards development for improved quality of life and standard of living for all our citizens. We hope to serve as a benchmark for all villages in the future.

resources.string: People volunteer for a variety of reasons - wanting to help others and serve society are the most common amongst them. At Anandwan, our volunteers don’t "work for, but with us" right at the grass root level to help us build on our strengths and achieve our goals.

Our volunteers get the opportunity to gain and share skills and expertise right in the heart of a rural setting, in a range of areas including administration, fundraising, renewable energy initiatives, sustainable infrastructure development, training and development, education and many more.

Whether you’re looking to gain work experience, learn new skills, broaden your horizons, fulfil your passion for environmental causes/issues or simply want to take a break and get out of a rut, we can help you to do something special.

We deeply appreciate and value our volunteers’ time and efforts and always look forward to welcoming genuine people on board. Your skills, energy and experience will help us strive forward to better ourselves each day and in turn provide you with the most rewarding, emotional and spiritual life journey that will surely change your perspective on life in a positive way!

The idea of `How to build/develop a man` found its roots when Baba saw the emptiness of the supple minds of youth, who were being pushed away from the idea of living a community centered and development oriented life due to prevailing socio-economic conditions and education system. Baba would always argue that if people affected with leprosy and other disabilities could carve out an oasis out of barren land and pioneer the paradigms of development, then why can`t people especially the youngsters who have able minds and bodies build a modern responsible and inclusive nation.\n\nThe solution was to kindle the young hearts by channelling their anxieties, desperation and raw energy on the path of development

This vision came to realization through "Shram Sanskar Chhavani" which Baba often refered to as a factory for transforming youngsters into sensitive, responsible, development oriented citizens. This was achieved by instilling the value of hard labor in their hearts and minds.

`Shram Sanskar Chhavani` is a week-long annual boot camp where young boys and girls from all over the country congregate, make friends, get sensitized and work in harmony with nature, building check dams, cultivating barren land, cleaning forests and digging lakes through Shramadan (hard labor). Working together, regardless of caste, creed and religion, helps them to develop empathy, secular values, national integration and sensitization towards the marginalized section of society and environment. Participants learn about current and potential challenges confronting the society and are encouraged to ideate and develop sustainable solution through interaction with their peers and subject matter experts on topics ranging from education, health care, livelihoods, agriculture, rural development and environmental conservation.

Camp Entries limit this year:-

New entires: 500

Old campers: 70

Vegetables - Self-sufficiency is what MSS, Warora aspires towards. Vegetables are primarily cultivated for internal consumption. The excess is sold in the local markets nearby. Many varieties of vegetables are grown here on an annual and seasonal basis like okra, eggplant, cucumber etc.\n\n" + "Fruits - Fruits are high on nutrients and it is important to include them in one’s diet. However, it is often an ignored part of a healthy diet. We cultivate various types of fruits like bananas, guavas and specially the famous Nagpur mandarins. For us, it is important to ensure that our residents get a balanced and quality diet.

Literally...Anandwan is a Forest of Joy". Sandhiniketan where I work is a "Home of Opportunity"... Anandwan has given me a big canvas of "Sandhiniketan" with various color shades of differently abled children, allowing me to develop my passion for teaching without any boundaries. I have found a new way of life.Working with our deaf, blind and physically challenged children, I get pleasantly surprised daily looking at their positive attitude and finding joy in small things. Every day in Anandwan teaches you something that will help you lead a meaningful life This has been an "Experience of a Lifetime for me!

Nothing so far has given me as much work satisfaction as being able to serve the ones who are not able to access healthcare facilities because of being differently abled or afflicted by diseases like leprosy. Anandwan has provided me a perfect platform not just to treat people as a dentist but also to increase oral hygiene awareness, introduce rural population to modern treatment techniques and facilities and reduce common myths and assumptions. And that is just the professional aspect... This place and people have that power and energy to change you for the better- emotionally, spiritually, professionally and bring about a drastic change in your attitude towards life
